title: Warren, Unlike Sanders, Makes the Medicare Math Add Up
summary: His plan comes up $12.5 trillion short, while hers spares the middle class a tax increase.. Bernie Sanders released an updated plan last week to pay for Medicare for All. The plan is light on details, but leaves the senator at least $12.5 trillion short of covering the cost of his health-care proposal over 10 years. It calls for some tax increases on working families, but the real burden may be much higher than advertised: Mr. Sanders may have to raise taxes on American workers by 16 percentage points or more to avoid multitrillion-dollar deficits. Fortunately, Elizabeth Warren's financing plan for Medicare for All offers a better alternative.

title: Bloomberg Sells 'Sustainability,' but Buyer Beware
summary: Virtue-signaling corporate standards may be better for financial firms than they are for investors.. Michael Bloomberg became one of the world's richest men by creating a financial software and data-analytics business to assist investors. He has since used his wealth to promote progressive causes. Now he's standing behind a nonprofit financial venture that helps others cash in on liberal corporate virtue. Its name is the Sustainability Accounting Standards Board.

title: Supreme Court to Hear First Major Abortion Case Since Trump Appointments
summary: Case will test new conservative makeup's approach to precedent. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court hears its first major abortion case Wednesday since two Trump nominees joined the bench, potentially signalling whether-and how much--reproductive rights may change under a bolstered conservative majority.

title: U.S. Orders Cap on Chinese State Media Personnel
summary: State Department to force reduction to 100 employees from 160. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is ordering China's major state media companies to sharply reduce the ranks of Chinese nationals in the U.S. in retaliation for years of tightening restrictions on American news outlets by Beijing.

title: Ideology and the War on For-Profit Colleges
summary: Your authors are correct that this regulation was implemented not to benefit students, but to punish for-profit universities on the assumption that all were evil.. Andrew Gillen and Richard Vedder's "Obama Did Persecute For-Profit Colleges" (op-ed, Feb. 26) on the "gainful employment" regulations took me back three years. Our company owned a large, for-profit university, Kaplan University, and I was concentrated on the truly crazy federal regulation of higher education. We no longer own the university (it is thriving under Purdue University's management).

title: FDR Was Right on Public-Employee Unions
summary: President Franklin Roosevelt wrote that the process of collective bargaining had "insurmountable limitations when applied to public personnel management.". Ken Girardin warns Virginians that they will regret it if Democrats, with total control of state government, legalize collective bargaining for government employees ("Virginia Is for Public-Sector Union Lovers," Cross Country, Feb. 22). New York state finds that labor contracts today dictate nearly every facet of public-service delivery, stymie innovation, drive up costs and taxes and are, in effect, etched in stone because of New York's "contract continuity" statute.

title: Senate Homeland Security Panel Chairman Wants to Issue Subpoena in Hunter Biden Probe
summary: Sen. Ron Johnson seeks documents, interview with former Ukrainian diplomatic aide. WASHINGTON-A top Senate Republican said he intends to issue a subpoena as part of his committee's probe into the work that former Vice President Joe Biden's son did for a Ukrainian natural gas company, escalating Republican efforts to put a spotlight on a leading Democratic presidential candidate.

title: Unlike Bernie, McGovern Came to Value Businessmen
summary: George McGovern wrote: "I . . . wish that during the years I was in public office I had had this firsthand experience about the difficulties business people face every day.". Regarding William A. Galston's "Sanders Takes Up McGovern's Mantle" (Politics & Ideas, Feb. 26): How many of the Democratic candidates have worked in the private sector before becoming "public servants"? Few of them. George McGovern, after retiring from the Senate, owned a hotel in Connecticut and went bankrupt. He later wrote in the Journal: "I . . . wish that during the years I was in public office, I had had this firsthand experience about the difficulties business people face every day. That knowledge would have made me a better U.S. senator and a more understanding presidential contender."

title: A Codger Candidates Satire
summary: Regarding Lance Morrow's "OK Boomer? Bernie, Biden and Bloomberg Are Older Still": I think the proposed publication would be better called "Codger and Crone," but either way, I'll subscribe.. Regarding Lance Morrow's "OK Boomer? Bernie, Biden and Bloomberg Are Older Still" (op-ed, Feb. 27): I think the proposed publication would be better called "Codger and Crone," but either way, I'll subscribe. Maybe the first issue could include advice on how to stop junk mail from AARP.

title: Ad Business Likely to Suffer as Firms Brace for Spread of Coronavirus
summary: Publicis unit, a large advertising buyer, plans to cut global spending forecast; New York Times warns of slump. With the coming U.S. presidential election and Summer Olympics, 2020 was expected to be a good year for advertising. Then came the coronavirus.

title: New York Seeks to Reduce Special-Education Case Backlog
summary: New York City had more than 10,000 open cases in January, and most of them were running late. To resolve a backlog of thousands of complaints from New York City families over special education services, state officials want to let people who aren't attorneys resolve these disputes.

title: White House Drops Nominee Who Questioned Ukraine Aid Suspension
summary: Nominee had warned that withholding aid could violate law. WASHINGTON-The White House has withdrawn the nomination of Elaine McCusker, a senior Pentagon official in line to become a deputy defense secretary and comptroller, after she clashed with the White House over the 2019 suspension of military aid to Ukraine, administration and congressional officials said Monday.

title: CIOs Act as Companies' Glue During Coronavirus Disruptions
summary: IT leaders are playing a role in crafting contingency plans in addition to making sure technology is running smoothly. Chief information officers are leading efforts to keep their businesses humming as the coronavirus outbreak spreads, reflecting companies' reliance on technology for daily operations.

title: European Nations Diverge on How to Curb Virus Outbreak
summary: Governments struggle to find the right balance between protecting public health and shielding the economy from disruption. European governments are divided in their response to the coronavirus, which has rapidly hopped across borders on the densely populated continent, as they seek to balance protecting public health with economic disruption.

title: Dow Rallies Nearly 1,300 Points Amid Stimulus Hopes
summary: Blue-chip index adds nearly 1,300 points in record point move as investors bet on lower interest rates. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rebounded from seven-session streak of declines with its best day in more than a decade, lifted by investors' bets that central banks can stabilize markets and shield economic growth from the impact of the coronavirus epidemic.

title: U.S. Airlines Face Test as Epidemic Spreads
summary: Disruptions related to coronavirus threaten a decade of profits at domestic carriers. U.S. airlines retooled their businesses over the past decade in ways they said would generate profits even during an economic shock. The coronavirus epidemic rippling around the world is providing the biggest test yet of those efforts, grounding hundreds of jets overseas as consumers and businesses scrap travel plans.

title: Apple to Settle Class-Action Suit Over Slowed-Down iPhones
summary: Agreement calls for eligible owners to get $25 per device, with an overall payout of up to $500 million. Apple Inc. has agreed to pay as much as $500 million to settle a class-action lawsuit that claims the company slowed down the performance of older iPhones to spur customers to buy new ones.

title: Pentagon to Get First African-American Senior Leader Since Powell
summary: White House nominates Gen. Charles Brown to be chief of staff of Air Force. WASHINGTON-The White House on Monday named the first African-American military service chief, nominating a veteran combat pilot and a longtime officer to lead the Air Force, Defense Secretary Mark Esper said.

title: Orin Kramer, Major Buttigieg Fundraiser, Shifts to Biden
summary: The hedge-fund founder is one of several prominent Buttigieg backers who have decided to support Biden. Orin Kramer, an influential Democratic fundraiser and hedge-fund founder who spent the past year helping Pete Buttigieg, is throwing his weight behind former Vice President Joe Biden.

title: 'Heavy Light' by U.S. Girls Review: An Ideal Introduction to Genre Experimentation
summary: Forcefully expressive music gleefully draws from across rock and pop history to create sometimes-surreal juxtapositions..

title: Ex-SUNY Polytechnic Institute President Sues Over Patent
summary: Alain Kaloyeros, convicted in a bid-rigging scheme, says school's research foundation deprived him and former graduate student of millions. ALBANY, N.Y.-Former SUNY Polytechnic Institute President Alain Kaloyeros and another scientist are suing an arm of the state university, saying it isn't doing its job to monetize a chip-making process they patented in 2002.

title: Inventive Percussion Without a Drum in Sight
summary: At a recent concert, the quartet Sō Percussion played glasses of water, blocks of wood, colored tape and more..

title: Tech Stocks Stage Dramatic Reversal Higher
summary: Rally shows group's resilience after worst Wall Street selloff since the financial crisis. The S&P 500's technology sector soared past the broader market Monday, a sign of the group's resilience after the worst Wall Street selloff since the financial crisis.

title: Court Weighs Government's Power to Deport Asylum Seekers
summary: Two cases pit authorities' campaign to curb immigration against guarantees of due process. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday in separate cases testing the government's power to rapidly deport asylum seekers without court review, disputes that pit immigration authorities' campaign to curb immigration against fundamental guarantees of due process.

title: Gilead Sciences to Buy Forty Seven for $4.9 Billion
summary: Biopharmaceutical company says deal will deepen its pipeline of cancer drugs. Gilead Sciences Inc. will pay $4.9 billion to buy Forty Seven Inc., a five-year-old biotech company with a promising blood-cancer medicine that could be on the market within two years.

title: Long-Term U.S. Treasury Yields Hit Record Lows
summary: Futures market expects 0.5 percentage point rate cut by Federal Reserve in March. Yields on U.S. government bonds fell to fresh lows Monday despite a rebound in stocks, reflecting bets that central banks will act to battle the economic effects of the coronavirus epidemic.

title: Oil Rebounds as Volatility Continues
summary: Prices stabilize after dropping Friday to their lowest level since December 2018. Oil prices rose Monday, rebounding alongside stocks with traders hoping that stimulus measures from global central banks will insulate the world economy from the fallout related to the coronavirus.

title: Too Soon to Buy Stocks on Coronavirus Dip
summary: Stocks seem cheaper but might soon look more expensive as profit and economic forecasts catch up with Covid-19 situation. Stocks rebounded sharply on Monday after a horrific week. Are they worth chasing? Part of what has made the market so perilous is that without the ability to even roughly estimate what the ultimate effect of the novel coronavirus's spread will be on profits and the economy, it is impossible to tell.

title: Waymo Raises $2.25 Billion After Courting Outside Investors for First Time
summary: Investment in Alphabet's driverless-car unit reflects the sums of money needed to continue developing robot cars more than 11 years after Google began the project. Waymo LLC has raised $2.25 billion to fuel its driverless-car enterprise, the first time it has taken outside money since Google began to develop the technology more than 11 years ago.

title: Biden and Sanders Offer a Choice: Unite or Fight?
summary: Vermont senator talks of waging a pitched battle against the status quo. Former VP proposes a return to normalcy that prevailed before Trump.. It isn't hard to imagine a Joe Biden administration in which Kamala Harris is vice president, Michael Bloomberg is treasury secretary, Pete Buttigieg is homeland security secretary, Tom Steyer is climate-change czar and Andrew Yang is commerce secretary-or, well, maybe special envoy for math and numbers and stuff like that.

title: Supreme Court to Review Affordable Care Act Next Term
summary: Justices to weigh lower-court ruling that tossed out ACA's individual insurance mandate. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court agreed to once again decide the fate of the Affordable Care Act, but it likely won't do so before the 2020 presidential election.

title: Grammy Organization Fires Chief Executive
summary: Recording Academy ousts Deborah Dugan amid conflicting harassment claims. The organization that hands out the Grammys said it fired its chief executive, Deborah Dugan, more than six weeks after placing her on administrative leave amid conflicting allegations of harassment.

title: Coronavirus Hits Once-Isolated U.S. Natural Gas Market
summary: Epidemic deals latest blow to domestic producers, exposing global links developed since start of shale boom. Fears that the new coronavirus might slow the global economy have sent already-depressed natural gas prices tumbling to their lowest level in years.

title: Never Let a Coronavirus Go to Waste
summary: Sellers of everyday goods and suspect guides on Amazon are reaping fat profits online. The coronavirus is scary, but the epidemic is also proving to be a scary good opportunity for some merchants on Amazon.com .

title: Iran Mobilizes 300,000 Teams to Stem the Spread of Coronavirus
summary: Tehran's new strategy marks a shift in its approach to slowing the spread of the infection after it was accused of trying to hide the extent of the outbreak. TEHRAN-Iran deployed drones to disinfect streets and mobilized tens of thousands of teams to conduct door-to-door coronavirus checks across the country, an indication of the scale of the epidemic here, where it has killed more people than anywhere else outside of China, including a government official.

title: Canadian Pension Fund CDPQ's Private-Equity Team Hit With More Departures
summary: Departures come as CDPQ aims to increase its private-equity allocation north of 15%. Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec, one of Canada's largest public pension funds, is trying to increase its exposure to leveraged buyouts.

title: Jack Welch, Legendary CEO of General Electric, Dies at Age 84
summary: GE executive led conglomerate with hard-nosed tactics for 20 years, then saw it dismantled. Jack Welch led General Electric Co. through two decades of unparalleled growth and transformation, with a brash style that single-handedly remade the conglomerate and changed the landscape of U.S. corporations. He died Sunday at age 84.

title: The House That Jack Welch Rebuilt
summary: The long-time CEO turned venerable GE into a greater success.. When Jack Welch started working at General Electric Co. in 1960, the conglomerate already was a roughly 70-year-old behemoth. It's a testament to his business acumen that in the 20 years he ran such a venerable company he achieved levels of dynamism that today we associate mainly with startups.

title: North Korea Fires Two Apparent Missiles in Its First Test This Year
summary: Pyongyang launched two missiles into the waters between South Korea and Japan. SEOUL-North Korea fired two apparent missiles off its east coast Monday in its first weapons launch of the year, ending months of inactivity amid a diplomatic stall with the U.S. and a national lockdown over coronavirus fears.

title: In 'ZeroZeroZero,' A Gritty and Global View on the Drug Trade
summary: The eight-part Amazon series is the latest to dig into international crime. A shipment of cocaine's impact on the lives of the rich and poor is given a kaleidoscopic perspective in Amazon Prime's new eight-part dramatic series "ZeroZeroZero."

title: Coronavirus Prompts Calls for Bank of Canada Rate Cut
summary: Majority of economists anticipate at least two interest-rate cuts this year, with first coming Wednesday. OTTAWA-A majority of economists expect the Bank of Canada to cut its main interest rate this week in response to growing concerns over the impact of the coronavirus outbreak on financial markets and the global economy.

title: Global Growth to Slow Sharply as Virus Takes Heavy Toll, OECD Says
summary: World's output could fall during first quarter, putting economy at risk of recession, group says. Global economic growth will slow sharply this year as governments attempt to contain the coronavirus epidemic, although the scale of the setback is highly uncertain, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said Monday.

title: The Gyms That Want You to Leave ASAP
summary: A new group of fitness clubs based around the idea of biohacking say their short workouts provide the strength benefits of traditional weights in a fraction of the time. There's a Holy Grail exercise entrepreneurs are chasing these days: a workout stripped of all wasted time and effort.

title: Chinese Businesses Are Running Out Of Time-And Cash
summary: More help from Beijing is coming, but the scale of the response may not be as large as investors hope. The last time most people saw a chart as cliff-shaped as China's February purchasing managers index was probably during the global financial crisis.

title: Amtrak Hires Atlas Air CEO to Run National Passenger Railroad
summary: New boss is Amtrak's third straight CEO from private sector amid a multi-year turnaround. WASHINGTON-Amtrak Chief Executive Richard Anderson is stepping down after three years and will be replaced by the former CEO of Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings Inc., which leases passenger charters and cargo aircraft, the railroad announced Monday.

title: Twitter Chief Needs to Pick a Perch
summary: Jack Dorsey's split role is a ripe target at a challenging time for social networks. When it comes to puncturing the Silicon Valley founder myth, the folks at Elliott Management at least picked a relatively easy target.

title: Saudis Renew Push for Output Cuts as Coronavirus Weakens Oil Business
summary: Outbreak is fueling Saudi Arabia's push for supply cuts, hurting the oil industry's profits and leading to project delays. Saudi Arabia is trying to persuade Russia to join oil producers in an emergency crude-production cut, as the industry grapples with oversupply and operational slowdowns resulting from the spread of the coronavirus.

title: Are You Lonely? You're Not Alone.
summary: A new book from former U.S. Surgeon General Vivek Murthy explains why many Americans feel lonely, and what we can do about it. As U.S. Surgeon General during the Obama administration, Vivek H. Murthy grappled with issues like the opioid crisis, violence and rising rates of mental illness and obesity. Contributing to all of those problems, he argues, is loneliness.

title: Saudi Arabia Confirms First Case of Coronavirus Infection
summary: Saudi man recently had returned from Iran. DUBAI-Saudi Arabia, home to Islamic holy sites that draw millions of people every year, confirmed the kingdom's first case of coronavirus infection.

title: Xerox Moves to Buy All of HP's Shares
summary: HP has resisted the deal while saying it is open to a combination on different terms. Xerox Holdings Corp. has launched an effort to acquire all of HP Inc.'s shares outstanding, valuing the maker of printers, printer supplies and personal computers at nearly $35 billion.

title: Greta Thunberg and the Case of the Muddy Carbon Footprints
summary: Eco-activists descend upon a treasured local environment.. Teen climate celebrity Greta Thunberg inspired thousands of British children to skip school on Friday and protest global warming. Unfortunately the young activists damaged the treasured green space where they chose to rally. Residents are hopeful that their resilient local environment will stage a robust ecological recovery.

title: Greek Soldiers Called In to Block Migrant Crossings at Turkish Border
summary: EU officials back Athens' strict border control measures in test of bloc's eastern borders. Greece rushed more soldiers and border guards to its eastern border in an attempt to hold back thousands of migrants after the Turkish government said it would no longer prevent refugees in Turkey from reaching Europe.

title: Western Asset Calls Top of Treasury Market Rally
summary: Firm buys investment-grade and high-yield corporate debt. Bond-investing giant Western Asset Management Co. is calling a top on the red-hot market for U.S. Treasury bonds and buying into corporate debt instead.

title: Nicaraguan Priest, Poet and Revolutionary, Dies
summary: Ernesto Cardenal, born into a wealthy family, allied with leftist Sandinista revolutionaries and clashed with the Vatican before breaking with President Ortega. MEXICO CITY-Ernesto Cardenal, a Nicaraguan priest, poet, politician and revolutionary who ran afoul of the Vatican for championing liberation theology and embracing the Sandinista revolution before ultimately denouncing authoritarian President Daniel Ortega, died Sunday in Managua.

title: Herbalife Sets Aside $40 Million for Bribery Settlement
summary: The Los Angeles multilevel-marketing company is looking to resolve investigations by the Justice Department and the SEC. Herbalife Nutrition Ltd. has set aside $40 million to resolve foreign bribery probes centered on its business in China.

title: School Trip to Italy Is Behind Rhode Island's First Coronavirus Cases
summary: All 38 people who went on trip are self-quarantining at home for 14 days under public-health supervision. Two individuals from a private Rhode Island high school who went on a school trip to Europe in mid-February tested positive for the novel coronavirus, the state health department said.

title: Point72's Head Quant Is Leaving the Firm
summary: Ross Garon to step down from post at Cubist Systematic Strategies unit. The head of billionaire Steven A. Cohen's quantitative-trading effort is leaving, a potential sign of the challenges traditional investors are facing as they move to embrace quant strategies.

title: Barnard College Slay Trial to Examine What Teen Suspect Understands
summary: Case will test young criminal suspects' comprehension of criminal-justice system and their rights. Whether young criminal suspects are capable of understanding the criminal-justice system and their Miranda rights might be tested in the case of a 13-year-old boy charged in the killing of a Barnard College student.

title: ViacomCBS's Pluto TV Boosts Marketing as Free Streaming Services Intensify Fight
summary: As the subscription streaming wars heat up, free TV services are also looking to lure viewers. ViacomCBS Inc.'s Pluto TV is launching an ad campaign to attract viewers as the competition in free and ad-supported streaming TV intensifies.

title: Spotify Builds a Music Experience for Children
summary: Streaming service courts future customers with an interface designed for young eyes and small hands. A new version of the Spotify experience greets the user by name, plus a friendly "Hi!"

title: Heed Biden's Call for Bipartisan Civility
summary: In an age of confrontation, his South Carolina victory suggests many voters have an appetite for comity.. Joe Biden has been mocked for touting his ability to work with Republicans, and for his optimism that he'll do the same if elected president. There are good reasons to mock Mr. Biden, but this isn't one of them. Politicians should be encouraged to respect their opponents. Voters tell pollsters they want elected leaders to put aside differences and work together for the good of the country, and politicians promise to do so. Mr. Biden seems to believe he can.

title: Turkey's Syria Border Becomes Ground Zero for Geopolitical Crisis
summary: The largest exodus in Syria's nine years of conflict has overwhelmed the ability of aid workers to respond-and military tensions threaten to spiral out of control. ANTAKYA, Turkey-Barred from entering neighboring Turkey, and fleeing a Syrian-government offensive, hundreds of thousands of people are crammed into camps, sharing few latrines and burning scrap and spare clothes to keep warm, sending up noxious fumes.

title: Philip Morris Appoints a U.S. Chief
summary: Finance chief Martin King to switch roles as overseas Marlboro giant eyes bigger U.S. role. Philip Morris International Inc. said it was promoting one of its top executives to a newly created role overseeing the U.S. market, a signal the tobacco company plans an expanded role on Altria Group Inc.'s home turf.

title: Collision of Two White Dwarf Stars Offers Clues About Cosmic Events
summary: Resulting massive star is one of only a handful of merged white dwarfs to be identified so far. The collision of two dying stars, known as white dwarfs, around 1.3 billion years ago has produced a star heavier than the sun with a rare carbon-rich atmosphere, a development that-if confirmed-could help astronomers better understand the cosmic events that made life on earth possible.

title: Bolo Ties: How Western Neckwear Staged a Comeback
summary: Fueled by a revived interest in westernwear, the bolo tie is popular again, popping up on celebs like Post Malone and Lil Nas X and at fashion brands like Prada. IT HAS BEEN decades since the bolo tie last reigned. Think back to Bruce Springsteen, brooding in a string-and-slide bolo on the cover of 1989's "Tunnel of Love," or Duckie the cringey, bolo-wearing sidekick in 1986's "Pretty in Pink," or John Travolta as the similarly outfitted hitman in 1994's "Pulp Fiction." In a 1990 yearbook photo, former democratic presidential candidate Andrew Yang, then a high school sophomore, sported his own bolo tie. By the turn of the millennium, however, the dangly tie had largely disappeared, though some western-wear adherents continued to embrace it: Representative Ben Ray Luján of New Mexico wore a luminescent turquoise bolo on the House floor in 2016 and quarterback Phillip Rivers wore one with a fist-sized silver slide to a press conference in 2014. Such exceptions were rare.

title: Meat Stockpiles Surge as Coronavirus Epidemic Curbs Exports
summary: Chicken, pork and beef stack up in cold storage across the U.S.. The coronavirus epidemic is exacerbating a meat glut in the U.S., filling cold-storage facilities with pork, chicken and beef intended for export to markets hit by the outbreak.

title: Canceled Games and Empty Stadiums: Will the Coronavirus Spread to Sports?
summary: An industry built on live entertainment and big crowds wonders what happens if people have to stay at home. The NCAA tournament. Major League Baseball opening day. The Masters golf tournament. The NFL draft, the NBA and NHL playoffs, the Boston Marathon and Olympic qualifiers all over the U.S.

title: Nokia's New Boss Must Learn to Fight Huawei
summary: The Finnish telecom-gear maker is shaking up its leadership, having admitted it needs to invest more in 5G technology. Nokia is famous for missing the smartphone revolution, but more recently it has shown signs of missing the 5G boat too. Incoming boss Pekka Lundmark faces the daunting task of seizing the technological initiative back from Huawei.

title: Supreme Court Declines to Disturb Ban on Bump Stocks
summary: Trump administration banned the devices in the wake of the 2017 Las Vegas mass shooting. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court on Monday refused to consider a challenge by certain gun owners to the Trump administration's ban on bump stocks, rapid-fire devices that were used in the 2017 Las Vegas mass shooting.

title: Sanders Focuses on California's No-Party-Preference Voters
summary: About 5.3 million people registered as having no party preference can vote in the Democratic primary, but they must request a special ballot to do it. SANTA ANA, Calif.-Bernie Sanders volunteer Kate Hallinan can't count how many times she's talked to California voters who are surprised or confused when they don't see presidential candidates on their vote-by-mail ballots.

title: Lyft, Uber Start Spending to Unseat California Legislators
summary: Lyft puts $2 million behind push to defeat assemblyman; 'They're trying to send a message to all legislators'. After losing a difficult battle in Sacramento last year over a law that could classify their drivers as full-time employees, Lyft Inc. and Uber Technologies Inc. are signaling they are ready to spend big against California legislators who opposed them.

title: New Jersey Lawmakers Push Data-Privacy Bill
summary: Companies would have to get permission from consumers before they collect and sell personal data. New Jersey legislators are proposing a bill to strengthen data protections and impose tougher restrictions on the tech industry, potentially following in the footsteps of privacy laws passed in California and Europe.

title: Congressional Primaries to Watch on Super Tuesday
summary: Parties will make their picks in races that could help determine control of House and Senate. The presidential primaries aren't the only important elections taking place Tuesday. In several of the Super Tuesday states, voters will also cast ballots in closely watched congressional primary races.

title: Photos: Jack Welch, Management Guru Who Ran GE
summary: During his tenure as chief executive, Mr. Welch drove General Electric to become the most valuable U.S. company during the 1990s. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Coronavirus Heaps Misery on Europe's Ailing Banks
summary: Shares of European lenders are pummeled again following steep declines last week. European banks have long been considered one of the weaker links in the global financial system. The coronavirus outbreak on the continent poses a fresh test of their health.

title: Stocks to Watch: Twitter, United Airlines, Harley-Davidson, AmEx
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Monday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Monday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours.

title: Prediction Markets Are Far From a Sure Bet Ahead of Super Tuesday
summary: Bets on Hillary Clinton, who isn't running, offer some of the best odds on one online marketplace. Betting markets show Hillary Clinton is one of the top contenders in the race for the Democratic nominee.

title: Fashion Exec Lauren Santo Domingo Uses a Closet App to Get Dressed
summary: "I wake up and I feel a bit like a robot. The app is telling me what to do.". In our series My Monday Morning, self-motivated people tell WSJ. how they start off the week.

title: Sarah Jessica Parker and Matthew Broderick Unite on Broadway
summary: In a conversation with their 'Plaza Suite' director, John Benjamin Hickey, the pair reflect on theater, marriage and gratitude. WHEN NEIL SIMON'S Plaza Suite opened in 1968 to good reviews and even better crowds, Simon didn't so much dominate Broadway-he was Broadway. Two years prior, he'd become only the third playwright in history to have four concurrent shows on the Great White Way. It was fair to assume that some portion of the audiences at competing shows were theatergoers unable to score tickets to Barefoot in the Park with Robert Redford or The Odd Couple with Walter Matthau. But times and tastes change. In 2009, when a highly anticipated revival of Simon's Brighton Beach Memoirs closed after just one week, he pronounced himself "dumbfounded," lamenting, "After all these years, I still don't get how Broadway works...."

title: A Day in the Life of Kanye West's Set Designer
summary: David Korins, who also designed the sets for 'Hamilton,' on redesigning New York City institution the Drama Book Shop. Raised in Mansfield, Massachusetts, the designer David Korins grew up constantly rearranging his childhood bedroom. His career has been an exercise in scaling up ever since. He worked backstage on his high school production of Carousel before studying theater design at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, interning at the Williamstown Theatre Festival and founding his own firm, David Korins Design, in 2004, when he was 27 years old.

title: WeWork Names Former Baker Hughes Executive as CFO
summary: Kimberly Ross will oversee the finances of the office-sharing startup as it struggles to become profitable. WeWork has named former Baker Hughes executive Kimberly Ross as its finance chief, effective March 16, a key appointment as new Chief Executive Sandeep Mathrani looks to move the office-sharing startup forward.

title: Why a South Korean Church Was the Perfect Petri Dish for Coronavirus
summary: Seoul had a technologically advanced plan against the infection, but a giant congregation with rituals demanding mass human contact-and secrecy-punched a hole in the defenses. DAEGU, South Korea-To enter the nine-story Shincheonji Church of Jesus building Feb. 16, the 61-year-old woman needed to press her finger into a digital scanner.

title: Michael Bloomberg's Global Business Won't Be Easy to Cast Off
summary: Democratic presidential hopeful plans to sell his financial-data and media empire through a blind trust, if elected. Michael Bloomberg's financial-data and media company made him the ninth-richest person in the world and is the source of the wealth he has thrown into his presidential run. But it could become a political liability if he wins-one that might be difficult to resolve.

title: Sports Service DAZN, Streaming Rival to ESPN, Plots Global Expansion
summary: Company known for its boxing content is expanding its sports rights and plans to launch in over 200 markets. The front line of the streaming wars is in Hollywood, but John Skipper-the chairman of sports-streaming service DAZN and former president of ESPN-is concentrating his firepower outside the U.S.

title: Tom Brady and the Wildest NFL Off-Season Ever
summary: Brady has been with the New England Patriots for two decades. Now he could be on the move in an off-season that could see an unprecedented game of quarterback musical chairs.. Indianapolis

title: Zoom Video Faces Health Check
summary: Coming fourth-quarter results will test the mettle of the coronavirus epidemic's hottest trade. No stranger to rapid growth, Zoom Video Communications now has to expand at ludicrous speed.

title: Leader of Church at Center of South Korea's Virus Epidemic Apologizes
summary: 'I am not sure what words of mine will do,' says Lee Man-hee, head of the Shincheonji Church of Jesus. GAPYEONG, South Korea-With a nation demanding answers as infection cases rise, the 88-year-old founder of a secretive church central to South Korea's coronavirus epidemic issued an apology.

title: Coronavirus Has Started an Unlucky Streak for Casinos
summary: Gambling revenue in Macau fell 88% in February, and fears are spreading to Las Vegas. The world's largest gambling hub just suffered its worst revenue drop on record. The bad luck could run for a while yet.

title: One Possible Bright Spot in Markets' Virus-Fueled Swoon: Mexican Stocks
summary: Mexican equities weren't hit as hard as some regional peers and some investors expect the market to receive a boost from the spread of the coronavirus. As coronavirus fears roil financial markets, some investors are betting Mexican stocks could eventually stand to benefit.

title: Fear, Anxiety and Guilt: The Psychological Toll of China's Coronavirus War
summary: The country's aggressive campaign of lockdowns and quarantines has separated families and left many isolated, adding to the dread around the epidemic. As the number of new coronavirus cases drops and life-or-death fears subside for many Chinese, the country is beginning to confront a new challenge-the psychological strain of hundreds of millions of lives overturned by the government's battle against the illness.

title: Super Tuesday to Test Whether Bloomberg Ads Pay Off
summary: Former New York City mayor has run the most television ads in Super Tuesday states. TV viewers in Super Tuesday states know this: Michael Bloomberg and his presidential campaign are on almost every channel. All day. And nearly all night.

title: Barclays Shareholder Calls for CEO to Leave Over Epstein Links
summary: Sherborne Investors said the bank's board should reverse its decision to recommend Jes Staley for re-election. LONDON-Barclays PLC Chief Executive Jes Staley came under renewed pressure Monday after an activist investor called on the bank to withdraw its support for its American CEO because of his professional relationship with the late financier and convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

title: Airlines Have Become the Perfect Anti-Coronavirus Play
summary: Sector isn't just pricing in the direct impact of the viral outbreak, but also a large drop in global consumer demand. Think that markets are exaggerating the risk of the coronavirus outbreak triggering a global recession? Airline stocks may be the perfect way to play that contrarian trade.

title: Pete Buttigieg Ends Democratic Presidential Bid
summary: Former South Bend, Ind., mayor ran campaign built around a call for generational change. Pete Buttigieg announced his exit from the Democratic presidential race, ending an improbable and historic rise from youthful gay mayor of an Indiana city of about 100,000 people to serious nomination contender.

title: How Coronavirus-Sparked Shortages Could Actually Reduce Inflation
summary: A prolonged chilling of economic activity would act to slow price growth in the longer term. This is the fifth and final column in a Heard on the Street series about the market and economic impact of the coronavirus epidemic.

title: Nokia CEO Suri Stepping Down
summary: Finnish company has been struggling to take advantage of a global shift to 5G mobile networks. Nokia Corp.'s Rajeev Suri is stepping down as chief executive, amid the Finnish telecom-equipment maker's struggle to take advantage of a global shift to the newest generation of mobile networking.

title: Election-Weary Israelis Vote for Third Time in Face of Deadlock
summary: Israel is voting for the third time in under a year after previous attempts have failed to return a government. TEL AVIV-Israelis went to the polls in their third national election in less than a year, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu sought to fend off a challenge from his main rival Benny Gantz. But voters fear that Monday's ballot could end in yet another deadlock.

title: Thai Billionaire Secures $10 Billion in Financing to Buy Tesco's Asia Assets
summary: Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi of TCC Group has submitted a bid for the U.K.-based supermarket chain's Asia stores. One of Thailand's richest men, Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, has secured nearly $10 billion in financing commitments from various international and domestic banks for a bid for U.K.-based retailer Tesco PLC's supermarket businesses in Asia, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Coronavirus Craters China Manufacturing Index
summary: Private measure of February manufacturing activity echoes official government data released Saturday. BEIJING-China's efforts to contain the coronavirus epidemic are weighing heavily on its manufacturing sector, with a second gauge plunging to a historic low as businesses endured extended factory shutdowns.

title: The Coronavirus Is Hammering China's Economic Outlook
summary: The fate of China's economy is of crucial importance to a world with few solid drivers of growth. SHANGHAI-China's coronavirus epidemic is depressing its economic outlook, with new government readings on the manufacturing and service sectors validating informal indications that the country is struggling to get back to work.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: AT&T Adds Another TV Option to Lure Cord-Cutters
summary: Internet-based AT&T TV closely resembles DirecTV service, but sidesteps the satellite dish. AT&T Inc. launched a satellite into orbit last summer for its DirecTV service. It would be the telecom and media giant's last.

title: Two Chinese Nationals Indicted in Alleged North Korean Bitcoin Hack
summary: U.S. says the men helped launder some of $250 million in stolen bitcoin and other virtual currencies. The U.S. indicted and sanctioned two Chinese nationals accused of helping North Korean hackers launder around $100 million in stolen virtual currency, alleging Pyongyang's hackers are receiving outside help and providing a window into what officials described as an increasingly important revenue stream for the regime's nuclear weapons program.

title: Coronavirus Cases Mount as Second Person Dies in U.S.
summary: Rhode Island and New York confirm first cases of the virus, while number of cases in King County, Wash., rises. New cases of the novel coronavirus reported Sunday, including the second death from the virus in the U.S., raised fears of a wider spread of the disease, prompting federal officials to ramp up efforts to test for and fight the growing health threat.

title: Democrats Race to Super Tuesday States With Time Running Short
summary: Candidates seek to capitalize on exits of Pete Buttigieg and Tom Steyer after South Carolina's Democratic primary. NORFOLK, Va. -Joe Biden pushed to leverage his massive victory in this weekend's South Carolina primary ahead of a wave of coming coast-to-coast primaries, as one of his biggest competitors for moderate Democratic voters exited the race.

title: Manufacturing Defect in Some Early CDC Test Kits Being Probed
summary: FDA commissioner says defect has been resolved and test has passed quality-control procedures. WASHINGTON-The Health and Human Services Department has launched an investigation into a manufacturing defect in an early testing kit for the coronavirus, according to an administration official.

title: First Case of Coronavirus Confirmed in New York State
summary: A state official said the woman is in Manhattan; health officials say risk still low. A woman who recently traveled to Iran is New York's first confirmed case of the novel coronavirus, New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo said on Sunday night.

title: Officials Feared U.S.-Taliban Deal Could Collapse Up Until the Last Minute
summary: Suspicion stalked talks that led to a framework for containing terrorism, reducing violence and withdrawing U.S. troops. DOHA-Until the last moment, organizers feared the smallest misstep might quash the signing of a historic deal between the U.S. and the Taliban, with mistrust and suspicion enduring until ink was on paper.

title: New York Leaders Miffed by Mayor Bloomberg's Take on History
summary: Campaign-trail claims for credit on schools, criminal justice and lobbying for same-sex marriage are disputed. Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg has both defended and touted his three terms leading the nation's largest city during debates and candidate forums ahead of the Super Tuesday presidential primaries.
